awd_titl_txt: TWC: Large: Collaborative: Living in the Internet of Things
awd_abstract_narration:
More and more objects used in daily life have Internet connectivity, creating an "Internet of Things" (IoT). Computer security and privacy for an IoT ecosystem are fundamentally important because security breaches can cause real and significant harm to people, their homes, and their community. These security issues also are very challenging not only because of the properties of IoT devices themselves but also because the users are diverse, vary in their technical knowledge and access to technical support, and include vulnerable populations such as children and those using in-home care technologies.  Moreover, additional risks emerge when users combine technologies in unexpected ways.
 
Meeting the challenges of IoT security and privacy requires a large, interdisciplinary effort. An effective approach to IoT security and privacy is holistic, integrating human-computer interaction, network security, cryptography, and pervasive computing. Enforcing cryptographic requirements requires not only building systems that can function on low-capacity IoT devices, but also using threat models that incorporate human requirements. Translating security and privacy requirements and preferences requires understanding what people want, presenting the technologies in a manner people can understand, and knowing what is technologically realistic. This requires behavioral and organizational research, with discussions involving public and private sector stakeholders.   The project is developing a foundation for IoT security and privacy that is intuitive, natural to the human experience, provides the necessary technical guarantees, and facilitates adoption by the larger IoT community of users and manufacturers.

por.por_cntn:
In 2016, Indiana University (IU) and the University of Washington (UW) received a $1.8 million multi-institution SATC award entitled Living in the Internet of Things. Grounded in effective approaches to Internet of Things (IoT) security and privacy that were (1) holistic and (2) integrated human-computer interaction, network security, cryptography, and pervasive computing, the research addressed a wide spectrum of emerging IoT vulnerabilities technical, behavioral, and organizational. Implementing a dedicated residential home laboratory, we were able to live with and test both systems and communities, as well as create both improved supportive technologies and generate significant broader impacts through education and information sharing with both public and private sector stakeholders.

Advancing Technological Solutions to Challenges in IoT:

Leveraging our IoT House Research laboratory and the security labs at both IU and UW, technical research included quantum resilience in low powered hardware solutions, secure MPN to protect home user DNS, API Privacy, COVID-19 contact tracing privacy, network device fingerprinting, closed loop detection for consumer Cyber-Physical Systems, trustworthy machine learning for supporting users of mobile applications, and device vulnerability detection. Results were reported to industry, military, and academic stakeholders that we have partnerships and CRADA arrangements with.

Researching device fingerprinting, Manufacturer Usage Description implementation as a tool for IoT device security segmentation, and the development of a home based MUDS visualizer culminated in a 2021 Capstone project which fielded a usable MUDS based IoT Secure System providing segmented device access controls to the home user via a mobile device hosted Dashboard. Tested in 8 separate homes, the system proved successful under HCI goals of acceptability, usability, and user control via a novel MUDS informed network architecture that produced a new viable residential IoT security solution.  

Advancing Understandings of Human Factors in IoT:

Human factors, both at the individual and societal level, are a critical component in securing IoT. If we are to provide the security people need with tools they can actually use, we must understand how people make decisions and implement security solutions. Our research included studies in measuring granular concerns of expanding smart cities, development of threat awareness tools, cross national phishing studies, a study on the efficacy of password policy based on a 1.3 billion credential database, risk communication and mitigation, access controls and authentication in home IoT, COVID-19 work at home technology usage, IoT product choice improvement through market indicators, and a series of accessibility studies related to security and IoT challenges among at risk populations.

Our multi-factor authentication studies were coordinated with device manufacturers and, in the case of the Yubico FIDO key product, subjected to repeated testing iterations. Advised changes resulted in improved implementations of their security key system, providing measurable increases in user acceptance and use. 

Advancing the IoT Ecosystem Through Capacity Building and Broader Impact:

We developed a simplified testing methodology to be used for threat modeling education workshops, hackathons, and educational outreach and tested it with a cohort of undergraduate students. Simple, yet solid, processes are used to (1) teach hands-on threat modeling, (2) introduce and teach testing fundamentals, (3) empower participants with both the ability to analyze and mitigate in the real world, and (4) produce a testing document that positions young researchers to present their findings in poster and paper forms.

We produced K8-12 educational materials including a Capture the Flag (CTF) gaming system designed to support low SES schools, using inclusive narrative storytelling designed to limit common societal and gender barriers to engagement. Additionally, we produced manipulative educational tools and implemented them at workshops in 2018-2022. In 2021, we fielded our CTF system with 3 locations of the Boys & Girls Club. In 2022 we fielded our manipulative and threat modeling educational tool kits with the Pre-Collegiate Women?s Cybersecurity Immersion Camp hosting students from 3 continents.

In addition to our graduate research students, the IoT house hosted 16 total pre-collegiate & REU students, 9 graduate interns, as well as the IU Cyber Security Club with a 250 student member community all working on cybersecurity research, skill building, cadre building, and career development.

Summary: Living in the Internet of Things catalyzed IU and UW into a hub for advanced IoT research as well as a center for increasing inclusion, skills development, and a capable pool of students who will be the cybersecurity experts of tomorrow.
